text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single full-page illustration framed by a triple-line border in red, green, and gold; no accompanying text visible on the page.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for haloes to denote sanctity; pale blue robes of the angel signal heavenly purity; red in wing feathers provides hierarchical accent; green lining and vegetation symbolize renewal; pink lake on Mary’s cloak offers warmth and contrasts with cool background; colors are applied in flat washes with subtle white highlights and minimal oxidation.

features: Vertical axis emphasizing the standing angel over the kneeling figure
Hierarchical scaling with the angel larger than Mary Magdalene
Diagonal gaze and gestural lines connecting angel to Mary
Simplified shallow groundline for both figures
Peripheral heraldic shield balancing the composition

decorative_elements: Triple-rule border in red, green, and gold
Heraldic shield in upper right within a cloud motif
Stylized border of three saplings as vegetal ornament

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill outline in dark brown ink with consistent weight defining contours
drawing_technique.shading_method: Very limited hatching; modeling achieved through tonal washes and white highlights
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Lack of linear perspective; shallow space indicated by a single groundline; hierarchical scaling

content_theme.scene_description: A single scene depicts Mary Magdalene kneeling at left on a stylized mound, reaching toward a standing angel at center. The angel, larger in scale, wears a pale blue robe with a narrow brown belt, has red-and-grey wings, and bears a gold leaf halo. Mary is barefoot, clothed in a purple tunic and pink lake cloak with green lining, also haloed. Both figures are set against a plain parchment ground with a single groundline. To the right, three stylized green saplings emerge from the same mound. In the upper right corner, a heraldic shield set in a cloud frame occupies the negative space, linking the sacred action to a patron. Spatial organization is shallow, with overlapping of figures indicating depth. Costume details include Mary’s finely lined drapery and the angel’s linen-like folds. Secondary elements include the triple-rule border and the heraldic emblem. Symbolic components: gold haloes signify sanctity; sprouts evoke new life; the coat of arms personalizes the scene. Compositional focus centers on the interaction of divine messenger and devout kneeler, with peripheral vegetation and heraldry supporting the central action.

religious: Angel with halo, red-and-grey wings, pale blue robe
Mary Magdalene kneeling with halo, pink cloak and purple tunic

technical_features.material: Fine calf vellum with smooth, well-pumiced surface; ruled with plummet for composition; framed by decorative triple-rule border.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Well-preserved pigments with vivid hues; minor background staining; slight abrasion to gold halos; no major losses.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf haloes
Fine pricking and ruling visible in margins
Underdrawing traces visible in drapery folds under UV light

secondary_functions: Display of patron’s piety and social status
Aide-mémoire for contemplative meditation on the Resurrection
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual noble or clerical patron for personal devotional use

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This illumination, likely produced in a Franco-Flemish workshop in the early 14th century, exemplifies the devotional aesthetic of private prayer books. The depiction of Mary Magdalene’s encounter with the angel at the empty tomb reflects a theological emphasis on personal resurrection narrative, appropriate for intimate contemplation. The professional execution—fine quill outlines, smooth vellum, and richly balanced color palette—indicates a high-status commission, reinforced by the inclusion of a heraldic shield, suggesting noble patronage. Stylistically, the work aligns with Parisian Book of Hours models, particularly in the restrained architectural absence and focus on emotive gesture. The hierarchical scaling and centralized vertical axis underscore the supernatural authority of the angel, while Mary’s receptive posture invites devotional identification. Technically, the layered application of pink lake, verdigris green, and lead white washes, combined with burnished gold haloes raised on gesso, demonstrates sophisticated pigment management. Iconographically, the sprouting saplings evoke new life and link the Resurrection to natural regeneration, a motif common in late Gothic manuscript cycles. Comparative analysis shows affinities with the Bedford Hours in color transitions and lack of pictorial depth, marking this as part of the broader transition toward more personalized, affective imagery in 14th-century private manuscripts.
